headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Rep. Greg Landsman (D-OH) is Interviewed about Biden; Trump Selects Vance as Running Mate; Johnson Used Old Speech. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: LESTER HOLT, NBC NEWS
utterances.sentences: Do you feel like you've weathered the storm on this issue of whether you should be on the ticket or not?

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Look, 14 million people voted for me to be the nominee in the Democratic Party, OK? I listen to them.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I'm not in this for my legacy. I'm in this to complete the job I started.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: One Democratic congressman who has so far held back on calling on Joe Biden to step aside is Ohio Congressman Greg Landsman, but he's been thinking about it. Here's what he told me last week.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. GREG LANDSMAN (D-OH): I'm getting closer and closer to appreciating that - that as much as I - I respect Joe Biden and - and - and what he's done, that what - what would Clooney said yesterday was really powerful in that he saved democracy in 2020. He's got to do it again in 2024. I want to go back home and check in with folks, you know, maybe one last time. However, you know, it's becoming increasingly likely that - that this is - this may be just too high of - of a hill for him to climb.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: I tell you what, come back Monday after you have talked to people back home, you know?

utterances.speaker: LANDSMAN
utterances.sentences: Sure. Yes, no problem.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: All right, and joining me now is Congressman Greg Landsman, who, to his credit, made good on his word to show back up and tell us what - what he actually thinks.So, Congressman, you went home. You talk to people. You've seen the events of the last week. Are you ready to tell President Biden that you think he should step aside? REP. GREG LANDSMAN (D-OH): Well, no, the - first and foremost, that what we all witnessed on - on Saturday was this - an attempted assassination on, you know, president - former President Trump's life. And it's a - it's - it's not OK. None of us should be OK about it. And - and that overtook, as you can imagine, the - the - the conversations that - that I was having at home. I spent most of Sunday with constituents talking through what it means. And, you know, overwhelmingly, I heard folks say, you know, we really do need to dial it back. I mean people should be leading with their convictions and - and fight for what they believe in. But to do it with strength and kindness and, you know, a thoughtfulness that we don't always see. And that's what we're expecting of - of the president. And I think he - he is - he's shown that. And the same thing with Mr. Trump. And he has said, look, you know, his - his speech is going to be about unity. The frustrating part of yesterday was that, you know, those of us in southwest Ohio know Mr. Vance. That's not who he is. He's not a unity pick. And - and Mr. Trump had many options. So, it was unfortunate that at a time when we all need to come together and - and be as thoughtful and careful in our rhetoric, not our convictions, but our rhetoric, that somebody like Mr. Vance, who's known for turning up the temperature, that's what he does, that that was unfortunate.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Sir, I mean, what was your sense of - of how President Biden handled the interview he did yesterday with Lester Holt. He did say it was a mistake to use the term "bulls-eye" when he was talking about Donald Trump. Obviously, he did use that before this happened. Context matters.But he also didn't necessarily - you know, I think one of the - the private criticisms Democrats have had, and certainly some public, they have been skeptical of his ability to really prosecute the case against Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: LANDSMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: And there certainly are plenty of examples of the former president turning up violent rhetoric, the way that he has talked about violent - other violent, political attacks, including Paul Pelosi.Did the president's interview give you more confidence that he is the right person to be at the top of the ticket or not?

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LANDSMAN
utterances.sentences: But now, you know, at least for this week, you know, all eyes are on former President Trump. And, you know, we're - we're - we're genuinely glad he's OK. That was terrifying. And as somebody who's from southwest Ohio, who grew up at around the same time and probably five miles from JD Vance, we're both from Butler County, you know, I - it's an issue that he chose somebody who is divisive and uses incendiary language. That is a problem. And I think most Americans are going to say, that's not what we want right now.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: All right, Congressman Greg Landsman, very much appreciate your perspective. Very interesting. I did not know you and JD Vance were from the same county. So, we'll keep that in mind going forward. Thank you so much for your time. I really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: LANDSMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: All right, coming up next here, a bandaged Trump appearing at the RNC. We're going to have more on what Trump told us former White House - his former White House doctor about what happened the day of the shooting.Plus, Trump's new right-hand man. We are analyzing the decision to pick JD Vance as his running mate. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I could have done better. But you, you got to decide if you want to be somebody or not.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: All right, 46 minutes past the hour. Here's your morning roundup.Donald Trump walking into the RNC last night, his ear bandaged, just days after an assassination attempt. During a podcast interview, former White House physician, the congressman, Ronny Jackson, offered this update on Trump's injuries. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. RONNY JACKSON (R-TX): Yes, it's far enough away from his head that it - there was no concussive effect from the bullet. And it just took the top of his year off. A little bit of the top of his ear off as it passed through. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Jackson says that he changed Trump's bandage before the RNC, and that the former president shouldn't need any further treatment.Senator Bob Menendez's wife's federal corruption trial has been delayed indefinitely. Her trial has been postponed multiple times due to her ongoing treatment for breast cancer. Jury deliberations will resume in Senator Bob Menendez's federal corruption trial today. The special counsel's office plans to appeal yesterday's ruling by a federal judge dismissing Donald Trump's classified documents case. District Judge Aileen Cannon sided with Trump's legal team that the appointment of special counsel Jack Smith violated the Constitution. The fact that this is way at the bottom of our news roundup tells you just how much news we are, in fact, grappling with today. And, on that note, let's turn back to this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) JIMMY FALLON, HOST, "THE TONIGHT SHOW STARRING JIMMY FALLON": Vance is an Ivy League educated attorney. That makes sense. Trump got a VP and a lawyer for the price of one. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: After months of VP speculation, it is official, Donald Trump and JD Vance will top the 2024 Republican Party ticket. Not long ago, the first term senator, Yale educated lawyer and bestselling author there was a self-described never Trump guy.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SEN. JD VANCE (R-OH), VICE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE (October 2016): I'm a never Trump guy. I never liked him. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: I never liked him.But now, as Trump's running mate, Vance has changed his tune dramatically and is turning his past criticism of Trump, or trying to turn it into, a selling point to try to convince others, welcome others, into the MAGA movement. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SEN. JD VANCE (R-OH), VICE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I don't hide from that. I was certainly skeptical of Donald Trump in 2016. But President Trump was a great president, and he changed my mind. And I think he changed the minds of a lot of Americans. It's actually important to be able, again, to admit that you're wrong. And I think I can make a good case to the American people, people who may have been skeptical of the president back in 2016. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Mark Preston, you can see there why JD Vance grew a beard. Those old clips -

utterances.speaker: MARK PRESTON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: I was thinking the same thing. MO ELLEITHEE, FORMER COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR, DNC

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: I was like, wow, he looks like -

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL DUBKE, FORMER TRUMP WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: Different guy.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: He's like 15, not he looks like he's like 60.

utterances.speaker: MATT GORMAN, FORMER TIM SCOTT PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN SENIOR ADVISER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, and he's still only 39.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Look, if you - if you're a Donald Trump fan, you're going to buy it, and you already have bought it. If you're an anti-Trumper, then you're not going to buy it. It's just those - the little nibble on the edges that we've been talking about, you know, over the - over the past hour or so about, is there going to be voters in Michigan and Pennsylvania, you know, Wisconsin, where we sit right now. But, you know, even as the map could expand, you know, for Republicans, does it go into Georgia, North Carolina? I just - look it, I think JD - JD Vance handled it as best as he could.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes.Matt Gorman, what is your sort of sense of what he is going to bring to the ticket, if anything, because, again, we do want to underscore, like, it's about the guy at the top of the ticket.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: Totally.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: This doesn't always totally matter. But, in a generational shift like this, Trump's 78-years-old. Certainly we're having - we had that conversation around Kamala Harris. JD Vance is one of the least experienced nominee - vice presidential nominees in history. Just two years into his first Senate term. What's - what do you make of all of that? GORMAN

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes.Mark, you raised what voters are going to think. Sarah Longwell, who - of Republicans Against Trump, she's a friend of the show. She's on - she's on a lot with us because she spends all of her time talking to voters, especially voters who voted for Obama - or, for, excuse me, for Trump in 2016 and then for Biden in 2020, trying to figure out what they're going to do now. They sent us some clips of what some of those voters had to say right after the Vance pick. Let's listen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) VOTER #1: I don't know much about him except I know he was very extremely anti-Trump. And so, it kind of like, speaks to his, like, lack of integrity and sincerity to not really - I mean, maybe he'll explain why he came around and it'll make sense, but I doubted it. VOTER #2: I don't have respect for people jumping off like that. There's a bunch of people that are anti-Trump and then all of a sudden, they're on it. But again, you look at all the sides and there's similar things going on with the Senate, with a House, with bills, so on and so forth. It's , it's - that's politics in Washington. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: So, Mike, that flip-flop label used to be kind of like the deadliest one in politics.

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: But it may or may not matter. Sorry, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: Well, no, no. I mean it took down John Kerry. But the - I mean, you can't have it both ways. We can't have people that get new information and then change their minds to be terrible but also it's terrible when people don't change their mind. So, you know, look, converts - converts are sometimes the best apostles. And I think that's what you're going to see with the vice presidential pick here. It is - he has explained it away quite, quite well. The one thing he also blamed the media for, which is -

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Well, why not.

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: Why not do it?

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: That plays to a Republican base. So, all of that is good.But, you've got to take the man at his word. And I think if he is going - to Mark's point, he's going to bring some energy. He is going to - he can articulate a lot of the policies that this campaign and this second Trump administration will be advocating for. So, from that perspective, it's - he - he - he brings a lot to the table.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Mo, Mitt Romney - Senator Mitt Romney, who I don't believe is here, I need to triple check that with his team.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Matt knows that he is not here. Yes. And, of course, I - that was actually the first convention I covered was Mitt Romney's Republican convention in 2012. And here we are and he is - he is not here at all. I mean, it's stunning.He's told his biographer, McKay Coppins, quote, "I don't know that I can disrespect someone more than JD Vance," end quote. And he's explained it this way and he was talking about Vance's switch from someone who was willing to criticize. I mean Romney had thought highly of Vance. He had read Vance's book, "Hillbilly Elegy." He invited him out to - Romney does this summit out in Park City. Vance had come out there. Jake Tapper likes to note also the Vance was once a CNN commentator in the wake of his book becoming, you know, all of this.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Even us.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes. But Romney - Romney says this of his decision to then go the other way, quote, "how can you go over a line so stark as that - and for what? It's not like you're going to be famous and powerful because you become a United States senator. It's like, really? You sell yourself so cheap?" These comments were made when Vance was running for Senate. Now, obviously, he's going to be a lot more famous. So, maybe it worked from that perspective. But -

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes, that - that January 6 note, of course, the very top line of the Biden campaign's statement that came out within moments of this - of this pick being announced.All right, we do want to talk about one moment that we saw on the floor of the convention yesterday, because, of course, after Saturday's assassination attempt on former President Trump, many of the speeches at day one of this convention were rewritten to try to make sure that they didn't include inflammatory rhetoric in the wake of that. That is until Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson took the stage and said this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SEN. RON JOHNSON (R-WI): Today's Democrat agenda, their policies, are a clear and present danger to America, to our institutions, our values and our people. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: "A clear and present danger," he said. Now asked about this, Johnson claimed that he planned on reading a different speech, but that the teleprompter loaded an older version.Now, who does that remind you of? (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You stay classy, San Diego. I'm Ron Burgundy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (EXPLETIVE DELETED), who typed a question mark on a teleprompter? For the last time, anything you put on that proper, Burgundy will read.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Now, OK, there before the grace of God go I. I have to say that.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: But this was quite an excuse.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: I can't even read off a teleprompter. Who am I to say anything.And that's the easiest thing to do, kind of.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Well, I suppose.But, Mo, I mean, this -

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: Oh, I don't know about that.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: No, it's hard. It's hard.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Well, yes. I - it's - it is what it is.Mo, you said this was one of the - like, this excuse, I mean -

utterances.speaker: ELLIETHEE
utterances.sentences: There are a few things. I've worked for a lot of candidates who have had to read off prompters, and you actually practice reading off of a prompter, right?

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. It's a still.

utterances.speaker: ELLIETHEE
utterances.sentences: I mean every one of these speakers is going backstage before they go out there to practice reading on a prompter. It's - it's nerve wracking for people.Having said that, I know plenty of political leaders, real political leaders, who will see mistakes in prompters, and they will figure it out. They will - they know not to read the bad thing that's on the prompter and they'll ad lib until the right thing gets up there. They'll figure it out. You don't just - if - if that was the wrong speech, he would have known it.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: Bill Clinton did it.

utterances.speaker: ELLIETHEE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: After standing (ph) they load the wrong speech in, and he ad libbed for minutes.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.sentences: For minutes.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, that's right. Very true. Very true.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Well, no I - that's - that was a surprise because he wasn't very good at that.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: He was not very good at that. And I kept thinking about, like, how many - there's instances (ph) of Joe Biden doing that where it's like, pause, like, last name.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: It's like, you know. So, it's - you're -

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Well, Joe Biden's done it - yes, right, exactly.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: Teleprompters - yes, teleprompters (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: We don't want to have a teleprompter war here.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, you're right, but -

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: GORMAN
utterances.sentences: Teleprompter is a skill. People -

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: I don't engage in it. Absolutely not. I read one every day and I know I'm going to screw up at some point and I am not criticizing anyone for anything.

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, I, yes, there for the grace of God, yes.

utterances.speaker: ELLIETHEE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I just - I hate the excuse, right? Like, he - the - coming out and saying, I read the wrong thing that was loaded into the teleprompter.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ELLIETHEE
utterances.sentences: Like, that's not projecting strength.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Well, and let's talk seriously for a second because the reason we're noting this, right? The reason we are talking about this excuse at all is because of the sensitivity around what happened and what everyone is listening for.And, Mike Dubke, I think the - the - what we saw from the president himself last night in the hall, the sort of look on his face, the demeanor that he had suggests that he is very much in that space, actually.

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: And I think the question for all of us who have, you know, covered Donald Trump for a long time, this is - this is an older guy who has been very set in his ways. We have gotten to know who he is. The degree of change that there is there, and the extent to which he is going to stay in the place that this assassination attempt has brought up.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes, but you didn't see - I mean the look that was on his face about this.

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: No, no, I agree. Look, at the top of the hour, I mentioned the same -

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: I mean that - that is related to Saturday.

utterances.speaker: DUBKE
utterances.sentences: I mentioned the same thing at the top of the hour. He physically looks different post Saturday. I guess the point I'm trying to make is, this has been a much more disciplined candidate than we saw in 2016 or 2020.
